content: Why is it a good idea to take steps to make my environment safer?

Nearly half of the survivors of serious suicide attempts have said that less than 20 minutes passed between deciding on suicide and making the attempt. If you have thought about a method or made a plan for suicide in the past, making it harder for yourself to access those potentially deadly methods can help you to keep yourself safe during a period of crisis.

Another way to think of this would be to imagine you were on diet. If you were trying to avoid unhealthy foods, you probably would not want to keep them around the house. You would be less likely to eat junk food if you had to leave the house to go get it. Similarly, you are much less likely to hurt yourself if your means of harm are kept far away.
What are examples of making my environment safer?
Give loved one the key to gun locks
Store medications in a safe place
Store sharp objects or rope in a safe place
Why so much focus on guns and gun safety?
In 2016, 69.4% of Veteran suicides and 48.4% of civilian suicides were committed using a firearm. It is worth looking over some of the things that you can do to decrease your odds of suicide.
What if I keep guns in my home for protection?
Consider keeping less lethal means of protection in your home, like pepper spray or a baseball bat.
Is there anything else I can do to make my home safer?

You might consider adding items to your environment that remind you of what makes life worth living (e.g., a picture of your loved one). These images/items can serve as motivation to use your safety plan during a time of crisis.
